articles.headline: Premier of Iraq Is Quietly Firing Fraud Monitors
articles.snippet: The dismissals of Iraqi oversight officials come as estimates of corruption in the country have soared.
articles.abstract: The dismissals of Iraqi oversight officials come as estimates of corruption in the country have soared.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is systematically dismissing Iraqi oversight officials, who were installed to fight corruption in Iraqi ministries by order of the American occupation administration, which had hoped to bring Western standards of accountability to the notoriously opaque and graft-ridden bureaucracy here.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Riyadh Mohammed

articles.headline: New Veterans Hit Hard by Economic Crisis
articles.snippet: A combination of factors including unemployment and injury has forced many veterans into foreclosure.
articles.abstract: A combination of factors including unemployment and injury has forced many veterans into foreclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a mortar sent Andrew Spurlock hurtling off a roof in Iraq, ending his Army career in 2006, the seasoned infantryman set aside bitterness over his back injury and began to chart his life in storybook fashion: a new house, a job as a police officer and more children.

articles.headline: A British Lesson on Auto Bailouts
articles.snippet: In a classic example of a futile government intervention, British Leyland went through billions in taxpayer money before going out of business.
articles.abstract: In a classic example of a futile government intervention, British Leyland went through billions in taxpayer money before going out of business.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  A faltering auto giant whose brands are synonymous with the open road. Hundreds of thousands of unionized workers with powerful political backers. An urgent plea for the government to write a virtual blank check.

articles.headline: Jerry Yang, Yahoo Chief, Steps Down
articles.snippet: Yahoo said Mr. Yang, who helped build the company into an Internet giant, would step down as chief executive.
articles.abstract: Yahoo said Mr. Yang, who helped build the company into an Internet giant, would step down as chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Jerry Yang, who, as chief executive of Yahoo, resisted a takeover bid from Microsoft only to later ask that merger talks resume, said he was stepping down.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Many Dealings of Bill Clinton Are Under Review
articles.snippet: Bill Clinton may have to make concessions to avoid any ethical conflicts if his wife joins the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: Bill Clinton may have to make concessions to avoid any ethical conflicts if his wife joins the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, former President Bill Clinton enthusiastically endorsed the prospect that his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, might join the Obama administration as secretary of state. “If he decided to ask her and they did it together,” the former president said, “I think she’ll be really great as a secretary of state.”
articles.byline: By Don Van Natta Jr. and Jo Becker

articles.headline: Chief Fights for G.M.’s Future and His Reputation
articles.snippet: Rick Wagoner and his company, G.M., have become the lightning rods of the debate over whether Detroit should get a bailout.
articles.abstract: Rick Wagoner and his company, G.M., have become the lightning rods of the debate over whether Detroit should get a bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Rick Wagoner cannot afford to leave Washington this week without at least $10 billion in federal aid to keep General Motors in business.

articles.headline: Clout Has Plunged for Automakers and Union, Too
articles.snippet: The Detroit automakers and the United Automobile Workers union face stiff headwinds of public opinion as they push for a bailout.
articles.abstract: The Detroit automakers and the United Automobile Workers union face stiff headwinds of public opinion as they push for a bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  When the leaders of the three Detroit auto companies and the United Automobile Workers union travel to Washington to make their case for a federal bailout, they will be flying into stiff headwinds of public opinion.

articles.headline: Web Sites That Dig for News Rise as Watchdogs
articles.snippet: As newspapers shrink, rival operations have arisen in several cities, forcing the papers to follow their lead.
articles.abstract: As newspapers shrink, rival operations have arisen in several cities, forcing the papers to follow their lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO  Over the last two years, some of this city’s darkest secrets have been dragged into the light  city officials with conflicts of interest and hidden pay raises, affordable housing that was not affordable, misleading crime statistics.

articles.headline: A Bridge Loan? U.S. Should Guide G.M. in a Chapter 11
articles.snippet: There is a fix to G.M.’s dance with disaster. Call it a government-sponsored bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: There is a fix to G.M.’s dance with disaster. Call it a government-sponsored bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tony Cervone, a spokesman for General Motors, has a warm and friendly way to summarize his ailing company’s ongoing dance with disaster.

articles.headline: Treasury Denounced Over Bailout
articles.snippet: Financial officials faced new calls from Congress to aim more of the relief package at helping homeowners.
articles.abstract: Financial officials faced new calls from Congress to aim more of the relief package at helping homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., on Tuesday rejected pleas to use money from the $700 billion bailout program to help homeowners avoid foreclosure or to stave off bankruptcy by Detroit’s Big Three automakers.
